pros: CSU has some tremendous talent! Great individuals that truly care about the overall well-being of the student.
cons: Unfortunately, there is a lack in overall organizational structure which I believe drives out some exceptional talent.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: People are great to work with
cons: Pay is low, needs an increase for employees

pros: Excellent leadership in President Scott, cleaned up all corruption and it's a great time now to be here. Everyone cares for the students and are here for the right reasons.
cons: Every department is under staffed and swamped, and there is no leadership owning the presidential priorities. So they or parts of them fall through cracks. She's getting there, but needs to make this her priority (installing excellent senior leadership over every area, then trust them to fill in their own holes). Also, President Scott is insisting on 5 days a week on campus, no hybrid work and doesn't allow individual department heads to manage that decision for their own teams. That's terrible for work/life balance especially after we have all proven how effective working from home can be. Also, it shows she does not trust her own leaders, which looks bad. For the non-student facing departments, this will be a deal breaker for good talent.

pros: A good place to start if you have never taught before, they will give new teachers opportunities.
cons: After teaching at this University for 7 years, I have finally decided I will never go back. I was consistently underpaid- they would change the rate after the semester started- and payroll would consistently not pay my full compensation, even after the pay deduction. On my W2 they would deduct about $2 a year for federal taxes, leaving me to pay hundreds more. The headache and unfair payment practices were not worth it in the end.

pros: Great history and tradition of a teachers' college since 1867.
cons: CSU is an incredible place for undergraduate and graduate students to obtain their degrees and certificates.

pros: State benefits and tuition reimbursement.
cons: Salary and the way they treat tenured staff.

cons:
Very limited resources which makes it hard to provide the quality services that students should be receiving.

Low pay.

review_title: The Best Place I've Taught at in 25 Years
pros: The students are eager, polite and a joy to work with! I have observed, in general, an incredible symbiosis between faculty and students. I have spoken with many of the professors here who are not only capable and caring in the classroom but also brilliant in their fields, winning research grants and providing international experiences that ultimately help their students and improve the world. Students I have spoken with have attested to being given these international opportunities, invaluable research internships, and perhaps most importantly, strong support from their fellow students and their faculty. Deans and Chairpersons with whom I have spoken are accessible and eager to assist faculty and students and, in the vast majority, very passionate about improving the quality of education in their departments. Everyone–faculty, staff, administration–is rallying together to weather the storm raging around funding issues, and we are keeping up hope and working to improve enrollment in these difficult times in a variety of ways. CSU continues to offer the best learning environment I have ever had the pleasure of teaching within in my 25 years of university teaching experience, and I fervently believe this university will continue to do so.
cons: Lack of support and respect from governing officials in Springfield.

pros: It is still open and maintaining.
cons: It is hard to receive a promotion.

pros: The pay is decent for the work.
cons: No opportunity for full-time position.

job_title: Substitute Teacher in South Bend, IN

job_title: Assistant Director of Career Development in Chicago, IL
pros: The pay was good but they let me go after a month with no warning or good enough explanation.  I was literally insulted and humiliated and I came from a job that I had previously been for 4 years.  I saw the president one day and I got up from my chair to introduce myself and he literally didn't even acknowledge me.  I know I'm not African-American but you don't have the right to treat me like that.
cons: No one was welcoming at that school from the students to staff to the faculty.  I got let go after a month of working there because my performance wasn't up to what they were looking for even though I didn't have goals; I was literally shocked.  Our department wasn't even open yet.  It worked out for the best though as I work for Northwestern University so in reality I should be thanking them lmfao.

review_title: I enjoyed the collegiality that faculty and staff exhibited throughout my entire time at the institution.
